title: Men’s Tour Down Under 2025 preview: Route, favourites, how to watch and start list
content:
Cyclist
Men’s Tour Down Under 2025 preview: Route, favourites, how to watch and start list

The gun is ready to be fired for the start of the men’s 2025 pro cycling season. With the women’s Tour Down Under now underway, the men’s peloton will soon get their own chance to race for the first time on the WorldTour stage after a long winter break.

Running from 21st-26th January, the Men’s Tour Down Under will depart from Prospect and cover six stages before finishing in Southern Australia’s capital Adelaide. The racing will test the riders in blazing hot conditions throughout the week, with GC obstacles at Knotts Hill and fan-favourite Willunga Hill.

Last year the Australian race served up plenty of surprises as teenager Isaac del Toro took a solo stage win, Scottish climber Oscar Onley claimed his first WorldTour stage before Welshman Stephen Williams claimed the ochre leader’s jersey after a close-fought battle in the GC. The two aforementioned Brits are back as part of a startlist that includes 2023 winner Jay Vine, Alberto Bettiol and Geraint Thomas.

After a long off-season though, anything can happen.

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025: Key information

  • Date: Tuesday 21st January-Sunday 26th January 2025
  • Start: Prospect
  • Finish: Adelaide
  • Stages: Six
  • Television coverage: Eurosport, Discovery+, Seven Network
  • 2043 winner: Stephen Williams (Israel-Premier Tech)
  • Most wins: Simon Gerrans (4)

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025 route

Like usual, the Men’s Tour Down Under focusses on South Australia, centring itself around Adelaide. The week’s racing begins in the suburb of Prospect before six stages snake around the region. Knotts Hill provides an early chance for a GC shakeup on Stage 3, but the main attraction is Tour Down Under classic Willunga Hill at the end of Stage 5. After that, there’s a city centre criterium stage in Adelaide to close out proceedings.

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025: Stage-by-stage preview

Stage 1: Tuesday 21st January, Tanunda – Gumeracha, 150.7km

The opening stage of the Tour Down Under follows a bumpy profile nearby the Montacute Conservation Park. The short 1.5km climb of Berry Hill could thin out the field, but the most likely outcome is a sprint once the finish line arrives in Gumeracha.

Stage 2: Wednesday 22nd January, Tanunda – Tanunda, 128.8km

Tanunda, the host of the race’s big start in 2024, will welcome a lapped course on Stage 2. The major obstacle is Menglers Hill, a 2.8km climb due to be tackled on three occasions. Tanunda has hosted three stages of the Tour Down Under since 2020, all of which ended in a bunch sprint.

Stage 3: Thursday 23rd January, Norwood – Uraidla, 147.5km

The highest point in the Tour Down Under parcours comes soon after the flag drops on Stage 3 as the riders take on Norton Summit. This initial shock will be tempered out with a flat 80km route before a relentless final 30km. The 2.7km Knotts Hill comes on two occasions before a downhill finish into Uraidla.

Stage 4: Friday 24th January, Glenleg – Victor Harbor, 157.2km

We follow the coast for much of the Stage 4. There are a few hills on the menu, but it should all come down to another sprint in Victor Harbor.

Stage 5: Saturday 25th January, McLaren Vale – Willunga Hill, 145.7km

Some things just go together, like Willunga Hill and Richie Porte. Sadly he’s retired so someone else will have to win. The iconic 3km climb (average 7.4%, max 15.6%) returns for two ascents – the latter a summit finish – during a big day in the general classification. Oscar Onley of Picnic-PostNL took the victory up here last year. Can the Scot do it again in 2025?

Stage 6: Sunday 26th January, Adelaide – Adelaide, 90.0km

The final stage of the race sees the festivities return to the state capital Adelaide. This classic finish from years gone by will see the riders sweep through the city streets on a short 4.5km-long circuit. There’ll be a rack of bonus seconds on offer ahead of the final sprint, so the GC could still be decided on the final day. There are opportunities for crashes and splits as well, so the podium contenders will need to stay out of danger.

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025 favourites

The Tour Down Under is always hard to predict. After a long off-season, rider form is relatively unknown. The hilly route and bonus second arithmetic can also throw up some surprise results.

There are two former winners on the startlist already: Jay Vine and Stevie Williams. Elsewhere, former Tour Down Under stage winners due to start the race in Prospect include Phil Bauhaus, Sam Welsford, Oscar Onley, Bryan Coquard, Geraint Thomas and Alberto Bettiol. Some of the big race favourites will also be racing alongside new teammates for the first time after making a transfer during the winter.

Cyclist’s GC ratings

  • ★★★★★: Jhonatan Narváez (UAE Team Emirates XRG), Jay Vine (UAE Team Emirates XRG)
  • ★★★★: Stevie Williams (Israel-Premier Tech), Oscar Onley (Picnic-PostNL), Sergio Higuita (XDS-Astana)
  • ★★★: Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers), Michael Woods (Israel-Premier Tech), Luke Plapp (Jayco-AlUla)
  • ★★: Magnus Sheffield (Ineos Grenadiers), Marc Soler (UAE Team Emirates XRG), Ion Izaguirre (Cofidis)
  • ★: Finn Fisher-Black (Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe), Chris Harper (Jayco-AlUla), Mauro Schmid (Jayco-AlUla), Lukas Nerurkar (EF Education-EasyPost)

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025: Live TV and streaming guide

The Men’s Tour Down Under will still be available to watch in the UK on Discovery+. Discovery+ costs £6.99 for the more basic package, which includes cycling and all other Eurosport programmes.

In Australia you can catch the action with the likes of Phil Liggett and Anna Meares on 7plus, 7two and 7mate. They’ll also be broadcasting the Down Under Classic in the evening of Monday 20th January, however this will be geo-restricted to Australia. Highlights of the Tour Down Under will be shown on 7plus each evening. In New Zealand, the race is being shown on Sky.

Elsewhere, coverage will be on SuperSport in Africa; NBC in the United States; FloBikes in the US and Canada; Eurosport, J Sports (Japan) and Zhibo (China) in Asia Pacific and Oceania; Eurosport, L’Équipe (France), TV2 (Denmark) and RTVE (Spain) in Europe; ESPN in Latin America; and Abu Dhabi Sport TV in the Middle East.

If it’s not being shown in the country you’re in you may be able to watch coverage using a VPN – Virtual Private Network – which allows users to mask their IP address and watch geo-blocked content from places where the race is being broadcast. One such example is ExpressVPN, which is well reviewed, helps users to find free to watch cycling, and costs start from around £5 per month.

Men’s Tour Down Under 2025: TV and streaming times

Stage 1: Tuesday 21st January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 05:30
7plus: 11:00 – 15:30 ACDT

Stage 2: Wednesday 22nd January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 04:30
7plus and 7mate: 11:00 – 15:30 ACDT

Stage 3: Thursday 23rd January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 05:00
7plus and 7mate: 11:00 – 15:30 ACDT

Stage 4: Friday 24th January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 05:30
7plus and 7mate: 11:00 – 15:30 ACDT

Stage 5: Saturday 25th January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 04:30
7plus and 7mate: 11:00 – 15:00 ACDT

Stage 6: Sunday 26th January

Discovery+: 00:30 – 05:00
7plus and 7two: 11:00 – 15:00 ACDT
